page.lettertext:
fol.64r
May it please your good L: A contrarie wynde hath kepte me from your l
re
of
e 22 of Marche, till
e 14 of this moneth. I also then recea-
ved an other from her
Ma
tie
to
e
generall States
by
e addresse of
S
r
Robert Cecill
, and in favor of
e debt w
ch
is owyng
S
r
Horatio Palavi-
cine
, w
ch
I exhibited out of hand, and also pleaded his cause as-
well as I could.
Their aunswear
thereunto, and to my g
na
ll
proposition
about
e mater of remboursem
t
is delivered unto me
,
but nothing sayed to
at effect, as when I writte my laste
e 13 of
this p
nt
, I well hoped to have heard in regarde of a further
offer of some actuall satisfaction to be made unto her Ma
tie
. For although
they were in talke how somew
at
might be done, yet doubting in parte
howe
e Contrey would perfourme it, and partly also howe her Ma
tie
would accept of a little, they grewe to no conclusion. All their
aut
answear in a maner, some certaine pointes excepted, is
e same
at
I signified
e 22 of Fe
b
when I reported
againe
in lyke maner
w
at
was replyed againe by me, and I know not w
at
more can be
added now unto yt. Againe I am persuaded
at nothing will
prevayle whatsoever I say besydes, because
e mater is so fitte for
replies and rejoinders,
at there would be no ende of disputing upon
yt. That w
ch
they have alleaged of their detrimentes receaved
by meanes of fluddes and water breaches, I suppose to be no lesse
then they seeme to insinuat. For there have bin some co
m
itted
to take particular information, of all
e harme
at hath bin done in
every parte of these Provinces, and their losses doe amount to a very
great su
m
e w
ch
is a principall cause of their slackenesse in assenting
to this yeres contributions. For
e Provinces doe co
m
only passe
their consents by
e laste day of Ja
n
or i
m
ediately upon it, and
now it soe falleth out
at only 3 Provinces
Holland
Utrecht
and
Guelderland
have accorded their portions.
Where in
e knitting of their aunswear they requyre,
at I would signi-
fie w
at
they had sayed by word of mouth, and is omitted in their
writing, I take no great pleasure in telling their tale, but yet to
discharge my duetie therein, this is all
at I remember
at resteth
unsignified. They say, they had oftentymes debated this mater
of my message, and were exceedingly perplexed in devising how
to deale,
at both her Ma
tie
might be pleased, and their owne estate
preserved: but although they had bin busied as never so muche
in any other mater, yet they founde yt impossible to doe
at w
ch
was required, and they thought very muche to be pressed unto
yt. We do all, say they, confesse
at we are bounde to her Ma
tie
nexte to god for this shewe of assurance. Wherto our Contrey is
reduced, for w
ch
it doth not becomme us to contest w
th
her in wordes
fol.64v
about
e equitie of our cause, but yet to say as
e trueth is [and every man]
knowes we are farre from
at tranquilitie, wherupon we [concluded]
Treatie w
t
her Hig
es
. It is also to be shewed at sins e [very first year]
we could never
enjoy
enjoy those forces and nombers, F[or which we are]
contracted and pawned our townes. And
at w
ch
payneth us [most, is]
to see
at her Hig
nes
doth continually disbourse very great so
m
es of [mony]
for
e paym
t
of her people, and yet maters are soe [carried that neither]
shee nor
e Contrey, hath
at use of theyr service as in [reason were]
behooful. For many more might be spared from
e [cautionary towns,]
and from
at of Ostend, then we could ever obtaine by any [instant entrea-]
ty; and of those
at have bin sent us, we were evermore [uncertain]
w
at
account to make of them, through their often revocation[s and]
cassinges and countermandes, and other doubtfull messages, [which put]
us cleane out of course of an orderly proceeding, both for cas[ting our]
plottes and atchieving our attemptes. Againe her Hig[
nes
may]
remember at in
e yere 85 before
e Treatie was concluded w[e did]
flattly then refuse, as the preface thereunto doth expresse very [plainly]
to contract for a lesser ayde then 5000 foote and a 1000 hor[se. ]
For we knew a lesser nomber would but drawe our warres at [lengthy]
and cause
e people to dispayer when they sawe
at their troub[les would ]
never have an ende, whereof we looked for no other but a [sudden]
composition and agreement wth
e Enemie. All this notw[ithstanding]
we cannot at this p
nt
, nor could not these two yeres bring [2000 men]
of her Ma
ties
companies to
e service of
e fielde. T[hese and]
other lyke speeches were delyvered unto me by worde of mou[th, but]
in very humble termes and dutifull sorte. To make [your L.]
partaker of my aunswears agayne, were to troble you in[discreetly]
w
t
a tedious recital. But after I had spoken w
at
was [meet for her]
Ma
tie
, I lette them understand,
at wordes and writinges, w[ere good]
cheape, and
at needes they must determine to make so[me other]
payment. For though their state was not so good, a[s was com-]
monly supposed, they were not yet to seeke of a competen[t means]
to satifie her Ma
tie
. And if they should not by somew
at
[show]
their thanckefulnes unto her, I doubted of
e sequele in [regard of]
her displeasure. But w
at
soever I could alleage they [were won-]
derfull vehement in all their protestations
at they were [destitute of]
meanes to satisfie her Hig
es
and
at they could
not
yelde unto [her]
not onely
at summe of a hundred thousand poundes, w
ch
your L.
doth requyre to be payed every yeere, but not a farre lesser sume
w
th
out incurring the perill of their utter confusion. And
where they understood
at I meant to convey her aunswear to her Ma
tie
and not to cary it my selfe, as they had Imagined I would,
soone after it was delyvered in writing unto me, they sent of purpose
fol.65r
to call me into their publicke assemblie, and there they intreated or ra-
ther conjured me (they spake w
t
such affection) that in a mater of
at moment whereon soe muche depended for her Ma
ties
good aswell
as theyrs I would take
e paynes my selfe to returne w
t
their answear
and laye before her Ma
tie
not onely those reasons w
ch
advance
her demaunde, but sith I knowe in lyke maner howe it stoode
w
th
these Contreis, acquaint her also of my self directly w
t
e
full estate of their affaires, and
at in every particular, which could
not be expressed to be perfectly conceaved but by verbal demonstra-
tion, w
ch
would cause her, they were certaine, to runne some other
cause, then suche as might ocasion
e flatte subversion of
e Contrey. They
would willingly have sent some Deputie of their owne, but
at it
could not be done wthout wryting to
e
Provinces,
w
ch
would make
but a longe worke, and was not soe convenient. Having made my
excuse for dyvers causes, but chiefly for want of her Ma
ties
licence,
they urged me soe earnestly and promised me to write soe effectu-
ally unto her, as I should not neede to doubte but
at it would be
well construed. At w
ch
their instant desyre, because I
doe consider,
at heere I can doe litle, till I see how her Hig
es
will
proceede upon their aunswear, and
at I may at her pleasure re-
turne againe assoone as any messenger, I have thought it fittest
for her service not to stand upon denial. But at w
ch
mooveth
me most unto yt, it is an ouverture made unto me in privat co
m
unic
ao
n
by a Deputie of Holland w
ch
whether it proceede from
e partie alone,
or w
t
some notice of
e States, I am not well assured. For he pro-
testeth unto me w
t
earnest assertion
at he dooth it altogether w
th
out
e privitie of his collegues, and although I doe beleeve it, yet I
cannot but conjecture,
at somew
at
hath bin spoken in
e meeting
among them, wherby he hath good knowledge howe
e rest are affected,
and doth direct himself there after. His drifte in
is ouverture is
soe to proportion her Ma
ties
demaunde w
t
e Contreis abilitie, as it
may be brought to passe w
t
e lyking of
e inhabitants, and both
be very honorable and beneficial to her Ma
tie
. Because
e mater
is but rawely imparted, and hath many pointes in yt to be duely
considered, it may happily hold me heere some 7 or 8 dayes, before
I take my voyage, I have sent the meane whyle their aunswear
before, w
t
their l
re
s to her Ma
tie
and
e
LL. of
e Councell
of w
ch
one doth concerne S
r
Horatio Pallavicines debt wherein whatsoever
hath bin further said unto me, then their writing hath declared
I will signifie at my coming.
Your L. being advertised
of
e troubles at
Embden
by
M
r
Gilpin
, I have sent you heerein
inclosed
e proposition of their Deputie to
e generall states,
contayning
e reasons of their taking of armes. It should
seeme by his speeches had w
t
me,
at
e towne is resolved to wryte
fol.65v
unto her Ma
tie
to crave her favor in their [cause or at least to]
intreat her not to hearcken to
e
Count,
who [prepareth as they]
say to subdue them by force. By a very good [means]
among
e Scottish nation heere I am certainely adver[tised that]
e
K:
hath bin mooved by
Coronel Stuart
, to pray her [Majesty, to]
enjoine me not to crosse his request. Howbeyt [it is thought]
at
e King will not wryte, I know not howe
e [Coronel meant]
it, whether indeede as conceaving
at I oppose against [him, or]
whether it be but a practise to make tryall how, her [Highnes is]
affected in his suite (w
ch
perhaps he is loath to [use, but indi-]
rectly and by circumstance. Once to me he will [not seem]
to thincke amisse of my proceedings in any other sorte [but that I]
wished
e States to deale in
at mater w
t
e mater
e privitie of [her Highnes.]
And sins I have made yt knowen,
at she can be well [pleased]
at
e K: should be assisted. Neverthles I am sure
at [they]
have made him no graunt. But of this kinde of [dealing]
and other lyke maters, I will signifie somwhat more [at my]
coming to yo
r
L: w
ch
I trust I shall not finde [unpleasing to]
her Hig
es
, both because my abode shall neede to be but [short]
wherby her busines is not letted, and because I [am assured]
will benefit her service.
And thus I take [my humble]
Leave. From
e Hage 23 Aprill 1595.
